title: Review: ‘Crazy Rich Asians’ Is a Party With a First-Rate Guest List
abstract: Jon M. Chu’s adaptation of the best-selling novel is a lavish, slyly old-fashioned romantic comedy.

title: These MoviePass Superfans Found Each Other. But What’s Next?
abstract: The service has become an integral part of the private and social lives of many — one user saw 19 movies in 19 days. But limits on usage will change that.

title: JT Leroy Film With Laura Dern and Kristen Stewart to Close Toronto Film Fest
abstract: The festival also announced a period drama with Chris Pine as its opening night film.

title: After a Quick Breather, Chloë Grace Moretz Comes Out Fighting
abstract: Ms. Moretz talks about “The Miseducation of Cameron Post,” her new film about gay conversion therapy, and why her Louis C.K. movie should never be released.

title: ‘BlacKkKlansman’ Is the Movie Everyone’s Talking About. Here’s What to Read About It.
abstract: We rounded up some of the best reviews, reports, essays and interviews about Spike Lee’s “BlacKkKlansman.”

title: They All Love a ‘Yellow Submarine’: Very Young Beatles Fans Sing Along
abstract: Families, most with small children, gathered at Film Forum for a special screening of the 1968 movie that let them share their love of the group.

title: ‘The Meg’ Is a Surprise Box-Office Monster
abstract: The shark movie was expected to take in $20 million. Instead, “The Meg” collected $44.5 million. Among highbrow films, “BlacKkKlansman” posted solid results.

title: ‘Crazy Rich Asians’: Why Did It Take So Long to See a Cast Like This?
abstract: With much riding on the first major Hollywood film with a majority Asian cast and crew since 1993, the makers faced questions about identity.

title: How Jason Statham Proves to Be a Strong Swimmer in ‘The Meg’
abstract: The director Jon Turteltaub narrates a sequence on the water with Statham going up against one very big shark.

title: Taraji P. Henson Reads Tracy Morgan’s Mind in ‘What Men Want’
abstract: With a new trailer out now, the movie is a follow-up of sorts to the Mel Gibson smash “What Women Want.”

title: Review: Looking to the Stars, ‘Cielo’ Can’t Quite Form a Constellation
abstract: Alison McAlpine’s experimental feature tries to film an essentially unfilmable subject: the night sky above the Atacama Desert in Chile.

title: Andie MacDowell, Still Worth It
abstract: One of the original 1980s model-actresses on her very modern maturity.

title: Matthew Newton, Director With Domestic Violence Record, Departs Jessica Chastain Film
abstract: The director stepped away from “Eve,” a movie being co-produced by a company founded by Ms. Chastain, a vocal supporter of the Time’s Up movement.

title: Eighth Graders Watch ‘Eighth Grade’ and Relate (and Also Cringe)
abstract: Teenagers turned out in droves for free all-ages screenings of Bo Burnham’s drama about being 13. The movie reminded them of their own middle-school hell.

title: Patrick Williams, 79, Composer as Heard on TV (and Beyond), Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Williams, whose approach blended jazz, classical and pop elements, provided music for film, television and his own award-winning records.

title: 3 Film Series to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings.

title: ‘How It Ends’ and ‘No Blade of Grass’: Grim Visions of Tomorrow
abstract: Two end-of-the-world films worth comparing and contrasting: “How It Ends,” on Netflix, and the 1970 movie “No Blade of Grass,” on Amazon Prime.

title: Review: In ‘The Swan,’ Ennui Permeates Rural Iceland
abstract: A young girl moves from the city to the country and gets her first glimpses of birth, death, sex and betrayal, but boredom is the overriding theme.

title: Review: In ‘Slender Man,’ Horror Emerges From the Internet
abstract: A digital urban myth becomes an evil force in Sylvain White’s film.

title: Review: In ‘Madeline’s Madeline,’ Hazy Boundaries Between Life and Art
abstract: Josephine Decker delivers an impressionistic portrait of a young woman’s volatile moods and divided loyalties.

title: Review: Spike Lee’s ‘BlacKkKlansman’ Journeys Into White America’s Heart of Darkness
abstract: John David Washington and Adam Driver star in a movie based on a crazy true story from the 1970s, pitched to the crazy realities of right now.

title: Review: In ‘Skate Kitchen,’ a Tight-Knit Group of Girls Takes In a Newcomer
abstract: A fictional feature that is more of a doc-narrative hybrid, the film directed by Crystal Moselle dives deep into a kind of hangout freedom.

title: Review: The Vietnam War, as Fought by the French, in ‘The 317th Platoon’
abstract: This revelatory French-made film, shot in the 1960s and directed by the former war photographer Pierre Schoendoerffer, gets a New York premiere.

title: Review: ‘BuyBust’ Delivers a Thriller in Manila
abstract: An elite narcotics squad has a very bad night in Erik Matti’s violent thriller.

title: Review: ‘A Prayer Before Dawn’ Drops a British Boxer Into a Thai Prison
abstract: Jean-Stéphane Sauvaire’s thrillingly impressionistic drama is based on the true story of Billy Moore.

title: Review: In ‘Dog Days,’ Finding Each Other Through Canine Fandom
abstract: In Ken Marino’s comedy, a love of dogs brings people together.

title: Review: In ‘Elizabeth Harvest,’ Forbidden Rooms and Stylized Mystery
abstract: Sebastian Gutierrez’s thriller is filled with surprises, but each one, paradoxically, makes the movie less and less surprising.

title: Margot Kidder’s Death Was a Suicide, Coroner Says
abstract: The actor’s daughter told The Associated Press, “It’s important to be open and honest so there’s not a cloud of shame in dealing with this.”

title: 5 Indigenous Australian Films (and One TV Series) Everyone Should See
abstract: Penny Smallacombe, head of the Indigenous Department at Screen Australia, shares her picks in this week’s Australia Letter.

title: Review: ‘The Meg’ Goes on the Rampage, but Barely Makes a Splash
abstract: Jason Statham battles bite-sized dialogue and finger-puppet characters in this nonsensical monster-shark movie.

title: Oscars to Add ‘Popular Film’ Category, Creating Questions
abstract: By adding a new category, the Academy Awards risk signaling that blockbuster films are not worthy of consideration for the best overall picture honor.
